text: Hey, I'm Priyanka.

And today, I'm going to
give you some tips on how

to find your best fit within
the product management space.

Before diving into
specific job descriptions,

it's important to take
a step back and think

about the different types
of positions or roles
that are available.
One, generalist PM.

A solid generalist
product manager

is knowledgeable in the
end-to-end product lifecycle.

They have the ability to create
a clear vision and product
strategy and also the roadmap.

They also have the ability to
actually execute and launch

and take that product
to market for customers.

These PMs can adapt very well
to lead product and engineering

teams, no matter what industry
sector, product domain, customer

segment, or technology
they're asked to tackle.

A solid generalist PM is a great
role for new product managers

to aspire to because
the skills can translate

so well to other more
specialized PM roles

if you do decide
to branch out later
on in your career at any time.

Two, inbound or outbound
or a mix of both.

All product managers build
and ship products or services

to their customers,
but some of them

build products used by customers
outside their organization--

for example, a paid
application for food deliveries

or a website that
is customer-facing.

These are called outbound PMs,
while others focus on products

primarily used internally
by the company,
and they're called inbound PMs.

Some roles also
offer a mix of both.

Internal facing
roles often emphasize

cross-functional collaboration
between internal teams

and the ability to
drive consensus.

For outbound PMs, some
additional PM skills

such as gathering feedback
from external customers

or handling customer
communications,

as well as working with product
marketing is also important.
Three, B2B or B2C.

B2B or business-to-business
product managers or enterprise

product managers are adept at
designing and building products
for enterprise customers.

B2B product managers
face many challenges.

For example, the difficulty
to have direct access to

customers often having to
go through indirect channels
for feedback.

But B2B PMs also
have the opportunity

to have a broad impact across
a very large customer base.

Also, their work can sometimes
shape an entire industry.

B2C or business-to-consumer
product managers

build products for
direct customers

who are also often
the end users.

If you love working on
end-user products more directly

and want the ability to
get more direct feedback

and measure the impact
of your products,

you will likely
enjoy being a B2C PM.

Four, more technical
or less technical.

Depending on your industry,
company, or any specific PM

role that you're
applying for, you

will need to demonstrate the
right level of technical skills
needed to succeed.

Some product manager roles
require very deep and specific
technical skills--

for example an artificial
intelligence or machine

learning product
manager who will

need to demonstrate
knowledge of concepts

such as how a model works or how
a model is trained with data.

Not all product roles
need to be technical.

You could come from a UX
design or a finance or business

background and still be very
successful as a product manager.

So if you're applying
for this type of role,

maybe more marketing
or design-oriented,

then use your strengths to
answer the interview questions.

For example, if
your UX designer,

you're already
good at design, so

start with that
during your interviews
and build up from there.

Five, domain or
industry-specific product
manager.

In today's very
competitive job market,

I think it's in your advantage
to use your domain and industry

knowledge as your superpower
when interviewing for PM jobs.

There are many jobs that are
focused on specific domains
or industry sectors.

For example, a martech PM
or marketing technology PM

has experience
building marketing
technology-related products.

You might be a user of those
products in your day-to-day,

so maybe you use Marketo or
Salesforce Marketing Cloud

One tip I have is that you could
use this knowledge that you

already have to then
interview for a PM role

at a company that builds those
marketing technology products.

So by using your strengths,
you can differentiate yourself

from other candidates
and maximize your chances
of getting that PM job.

I hope this video
helped you learn

more about the different types
of product management roles

out there and what your
possibilities are so

that you can then find a role
that is the perfect fit for you.
[AUDIO LOGO]
